title: When will Lebanon next hold parliamentary elections?
preds: Elections due this Sunday  ex-pats already voted https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-61434031
Voting for ex-pats already underway, elections ready for 15th of May  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/5/6/lebanon-expatriates-vote-parliamentary-elections

Leaders want the calm to last through both Eid holidays.  But waiting too long for elections will cause simmering discontent to boil over.  Lebanese citizens are more than ready to rebuild.   https://www.thenationalnews.com/mena/lebanon/2021/11/17/lebanese-diaspora-registering-online-for-elections-say-they-have-a-duty-to-vote/
Expats going to start voting, about 11 days out now and seems like all organized to go without disruption...

Apart to be firmly scheduled for 15 May. Can anyone better informed than me (doesn't take much) explain why we should expect a postponement? No-one is expecting the French election postponed for instance.
Tweaking slightly. Seems all on track to vote May 15 despite efforts to postpone. Can't rule out something getting in the way but so far seems on track.

https://the-levant.com/lebanon-postponing-municipal-elections-in-wake-of-ukraine-food-crisis/ Municipal and mayoral elections possibly postponed to May 2023 (subject to Parliamentary approval), but still remains to be seen whether Parliamentary elections will likewise be postponed given the wheat shortages.

Takes quite a long time to prep elections.
31 May is only 100ish days.
Will may be there, but logistics...

Most of the partys/leaders say the want to hold elections in may. However how credible these statements are is hard to determine. Possible reasons to postpone the election would be the setup of Megacenters which has been rejected by the parliament.[1] A second one would be possible food shortages as a result of the war in Ukraine. This was already given as reason to postpone municipal elections. [2] [1] https://www.the961.com/lebanon-postponed-megacenter-proposal-2026/

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/3/8/lebanese-fearful-as-fuel-and-wheat-shortage-deepens Upping the probability of a delay to 1 in 3, given that Lebanon's Ukraine-induced wheat shortage (only one-month's supply left nationally) as well as other shortages (fuel and energy price spikes) meaning that the coming circumstances for an election are not exactly auspicious.
Increasing my confidence given time passing and this announcement: https://ec.europa.eu/neighbourhood-enlargement/news/lebanon-european-union-deploys-election-observation-mission-2022-02-23_en

Cynicsm..
From what I read, the political equilibrium in Lebanon is unchanging..

19 Oct - announced March date for elections https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/19/lebanon-sets-march-date-parliamentary-election 27 Dec - delayed elections to new date of May 15th.  https://www.thenationalnews.com/mena/lebanon/2021/12/27/lebanon-to-hold-parliamentary-election-on-may-15/ 12 Feb - International pressure (from China, France, Germany, Italy, Russia, UK, USA, EU and the Arab League) to hold the elections on time:  https://english.aawsat.com/home/article/3470856/lebanon-int%E2%80%99l-pressure-hold-parliamentary-elections-time
Updating up as time passes with no delay.

Inverting time period based on President Auon's announcement of 15 May. Will have to monitor for potential Ramadan effects and potential delays. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-lebanon-election-idUSKBN2J60OI

I understand that the Lebanese Parliament amended the new electoral law, and the Lebanese President's appeal did not proceed. Now the new electoral law comes into force. They postponed the last general election three times, but there was a specific background. Before April, they already said no. Maybe, the politicians are a little scared about the youth vote, so the sooner, the better (for them).

New articles came out that I missed last week: https://www.thenationalnews.com/mena/lebanon/2021/12/29/aoun-approves-may-15-for-lebanons-legislative-elections/ &  https://www.thenationalnews.com/mena/lebanon/2021/12/29/aoun-approves-may-15-for-lebanons-legislative-elections/  Given the new approved Dat of May 15 -- I am boosting my prediction to Option 2 to 80% chance. I never put a zero % chance of anything so I'm keeping option 1 at 2% in the off-chance something changes. With that said, can never rule out another delay so I'm put a 25% chance of a post-June election and then weighed that down to be a bit extreme.
Leaning more into third bin because there seems to be legitimate wisdom there.

Nudge to crowd median again, but may have to nudge back to bin 1 because it feels more 50% for that bin than where I currently am which is 43%. But I feel the 43% is more appropriate right now than an in-between answer of say 47%. Uncertain whether I have crucial info that crowd does not possess so that is pending until further discussion.

Okay, they've already been delayed once. So, we have two bits of information here: - Of the regularly scheduled elections, only one (~15%) has been postponed (a bunch of times)
- Of elections that have been postponed once (1!), 100% have been postponed again (ha-ha). Earlier, I said that the base rate for non-postponement is 70%, but now the election has already been postponed two months. Should we conclude that it's likely to be postponed again? I'm really not sure- as I said in my first forecast, the situation previously was really different. I'm inclined not to update down too much.
Too many problems there so it will be pushed back
spineless politicians will try to postpone it to maintain their powerbases, but maybe face reality that push them into acceptance of the need for election in due time

"The only remaining possibility for Lebanon to transition out of its current decayed situation to a reform path is to make sure that the 2022 general election allows a critical mass of reform-minded figures who are not subject to the intimidation or limitations of the largest political parties to make it to the parliament." (29 June 2021)
https://www.usip.org/publications/2021/06/what-could-make-or-break-lebanons-2022-general-election "Mr Aoun would like to hand his office off to his son in law, Gebran Bassil, but it is evident that Mr Bassil does not enjoy majority support in Parliament. [...] Mr Bassil’s political rivals, and they are many, would be delighted by such an outcome, which is evidently why they agreed to a March election deadline. Their assumption appears to be that the President and his son in law are likely to lose votes in Christian-majority constituencies because of Lebanon’s dire situation; therefore, it is best to give them a shorter timeframe in which to prepare. Mr Aoun, in turn, has said he would not sign the decree for March elections, and would only do so if elections are held in May." (23 November 2021)
https://www.thenationalnews.com/opinion/comment/2021/11/23/lebanons-election-debacle-to-come/

Adjusting....
But no news of postponement

https://www.france24.com/en/middle-east/20211119-expats-mobilize-lebanon-s-2022-election-the-needed-seed-of-change

Given the date has been set for end of March based on latest parliament vote - I think this deserves quite a bit of weight.
Possible the thorny issue of the right of diaspora to vote may cause an issue but no indication it will cause any escalation at this point.

I watched @preciselylogan 's video which gave me one datapoint of the outside view -- in which 61.8% of elections scheduled over the last year or so were postponed due to COVID-19 or so. Not a perfect outside view but certainly one to keep in mind. Further, I referred to @mattlerner 's comment which suggested in Lebannon the base rate for non-postponement is 70%. I give much more credence to that metric so wanted to heavily weigh my outside view there to begin. So I started at 70% and then took some off given Logan's datapoint. So starting off I'll give the Before Apri the highest likelihood. Beyond that, I'm giving the "not before June 1" a slightly larger likelihood of happening given the country's motivation not to host the election during the fasting month of Ramandan -- which takes a lot of time off the table for the "Between April, May" option. That said, I've also referred to a couple of articles (https://www.reuters.com/markets/asia/lebanese-president-baulks-march-polls-amid-economic-meltdown-2021-11-19/ and https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/geagea-says-delaying-vote-would-condemn-lebanon-slow-death-2021-11-30/) which do suggest some likelihood of a postponement -- or at least some contempt for the March date. For now, I'll stick to a ~2/3 chance it's ontime with a 1/3 chance is gets postponed, with a skew towards June+.

Since elections started being held again in 1992, there have been only six (!), an average of about 0.3 a year, so naively I'd imagine a 2.5% chance in any given month, and a 10% chance of them being held before April. But that's a bit stupid, seeing as how a date has already been set! (https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/19/lebanon-sets-march-date-parliamentary-election). Let's go back to the last election, in 2018. That was postponed a ton of times, but importantly the initial postponement was set to be for at least two years. They did it right up against the deadline, under a month before the scheduled time. Also importantly, the ongoing Syrian civil war was a factor - that seems to be somewhat less of an issue this time. Here's another way of looking at it- of the last nine *scheduled* elections, three were postponed, so really the base rate for non-postponement is about 70%. Honestly, it feels a bit higher- let's say 75%. If it is delayed, I'm betting it's more likely to be delayed past June, but I'm not totally sure. Splitting the difference. Last time around, the parliament announced May elections in mid-December, and stuck to the plan.

Explanation video here: https://youtu.be/HOZiVAw27C8 -- Bumped my outcome up confidence in the first bucket up some as the crowd moves towards it and we get closer to March with no contradicting information.

After the end of the civil war, the first general elections were held at 1992. If elections would have followed without disruptions, there would have been 7 general elections already. Instead, there has only been 5 held in time, so roughly 70% of elections were in time. I would adjust on this rate somewhat, since  there was another state's military presence inside the country for long, which makes this rate not so convincing. But for the time being I do not know how to update this.   There is basically no chance for and April-May election because of Ramadan, so the remaining 30% goes to the third bucket.

The 2022 Lebanese general election is the upcoming general election in Lebanon, scheduled for March 27, 2022. 
The election was originally set to take place in May 8. However, Lebanon’s parliament has voted to set a date of March 27 next year to hold a parliamentary election. 
Due to the ongoing political and economic crisis, as well as the controversial electoral law, there has been speculation that the election could be postponed.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Lebanese_general_election  The Lebanese parliament has again backed holding a parliamentary election in March next year, despite President Michel Aoun’s objections.
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/28/mps-walk-out-lebanon-parliament-votes-for-march-2022-poll  Lebanon has a complex electoral system designed to maintain civil peace in a country where Sunnis, Shi'ites, Christians and Druze fought numerous civil wars since independence in 1943 … The president must be a Maronite Christian, the prime minister a Sunni Muslim and the parliament speaker a Shi'ite Muslim, representing the three biggest groups in parliament.
With two notable gaps (1972-1992 and 2009-2018), Lebanon has held periodic elections since its independence in 1943.
The 2018 General elections were held in Lebanon on 6 May 2018. Although originally scheduled for 2013, the election was postponed three times in 2013, 2014 and 2017 under various pretexts, including the security situation, the failure of the Parliament to elect a new President, and the technical requirements of holding an election. A new electoral law adopted in 2017 provides a proportional representation system for the first time.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2018_Lebanese_general_election => Since there is not much dispute on the law anymore, and with the Parliament's approval, I think it's in Lebanon's best interest to go ahead as scheduled. Any postponement might lead to more destabilization and delay any attempt to bring some normality back to the country.  Also nice comments by @preciselylogan https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1358364

There has only been two previous instances of election postponement in Lebanon ( 1972-1992 and 2007-2018) Najib Mikati is a Billionaire  and one of the richest Lebanese citizens who has close ties with Bank Audi the largest bank which is the largest industry in Lebanon. He also happens to be the Prime Minister. Both of these entities are seeking greater funding from the IMF. The IMF wants to see effective governance.  Hypothesis: In the case of a democracy an election is a very visible symbolic act for effective governance. Made more symbolic by the postponement during 2009-2018. The worsening economic situation is driving the push for a more rapid election.  Parliament voted on an earlier date which pushes the election into the first bucket. The President (Michel Aoun) sent the law back per the constitution it must be overridden by the parliament with an absolute majority. They cleared that hurdle and Aoun's team appealed to the constitutional council. States his party (FMP which is losing support) will abide by the decision.  Notably Aoun chose Mikati for the job (per the constitution) of Prime Minister. Hunch: Aoun's challenges while visible are political in nature and he doesn't intend on winning.  Parliamentary support, Prime Minister and Industry Support, Economic Situation driving earlier date, IMF influence. >> Bucket 1 President Aoun, Original Date >> Bucket 2 Potential Wildcard Events, Security Situation devolves >>Bucket 3

Elections are scheduled for 27th March. Although there are pressure it seems reasonable that this timetable will be stuck to - not least because IMF/Western support is likely to be contingent on continuing the democratic process. Highly unlikely to be between April and May because of Ramadan. There's a chance things could go very wrong and the elections slip to after June.
State elections consume considerable resources and require adequate governance to be delivered,  all things sadly currently lacking in the Lebanon.
They will happen next year but probably not on time

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/28/mps-walk-out-lebanon-parliament-votes-for-march-2022-poll
This may be just the beginning of a long and tedious dance.  Stay tuned.

Although  there is a lot of political turmoil, the Lebanese people have begun to see the power of people in numbers and are registering to vote. Calls to push the election point towards an election that may actually happen close to the date expected. https://www.thenationalnews.com/mena/lebanon/2021/11/17/lebanese-diaspora-registering-online-for-elections-say-they-have-a-duty-to-vote/
